title: A Cincinnati Neighborhood With a Presidential Past
text:
Of Cincinnati’s 52 neighborhoods, Mt. Adams, on a hill east of downtown, is one of the southwestern Ohio city’s most historic communities. Its first road dates back to 1793, and its name pays homage to President John Quincy Adams, who came to town in 1843 to dedicate the Cincinnati Observatory. The area has a 19th century European mountain village vibe, with 680 of its roughly 1,000 houses built before 1939 on narrow streets abutting the landmark Eden Park. Today, Mt. Adams commands some of the priciest residential real estate in Cincinnati proper. The approximately 1,500-person neighborhood with a median household income of $99,000, according to census data, attracts both young professionals and retirees looking for a walkable area that’s a five minute drive from downtown.

Illustration: Sanna Mander

Notable stops and shops

Bow Tie Café

Former Cincinnati Bengals linebacker Dhani Jones is one of the co-founders of this all-day restaurant that morphs into a wine bar in the evening. It’s been a Mt. Adams staple since 2010.

Cincinnati Art Museum

The museum is one of the United States’ oldest art institutions, dating to 1886. All the big names (Matisse, Monet, Picasso, Van Gough) are present in the collection of more than 67,000 artworks spanning 6,000 years.

Cincinnati Playhouse in the Park

The Tony Award-winning playhouse launched in 1959 and produces a wide variety of productions 10 months out of the year.

Mt. Adams Bar & Grill

While the restaurant was the first drinking establishment in Ohio to obtain a liquor license in 1933, its roots date back to a Prohibition-era speakeasy owned by bootlegger George Remus. The food is traditional pub fare; order The Broadcaster burger on grilled Jewish rye.

Event of the year

Holy Cross-Immaculata church. Photo: Albert Cesare/Associated Press

Every year on Good Friday since 1860, several thousand people from all over pilgrimage to Holy Cross-Immaculata to say a silent prayer on each of the church’s 100 or so steps.

Advice for the buyer

The houses—which generally range from two- and three-stories in a variety of architectural styles —sit on hilly streets that make street parking limited. A garage is a plus.

On the rise

Ten minutes from Mt. Adams and also in the 45202 zip code is Over-the-Rhine. In the 1830s, the 360-acre neighborhood was home to a large swath of German immigrants. It started to decline in the 1900s, and by the early 2000s, it was dubbed one of America’s most dangerous neighborhoods. In 2006, the area was put on the National Trust for Historic Preservation’s list of the “Eleven Most Endangered Historic Places in America.” Cincinnati rallied the community, which has since been revitalized.

3 bedrooms, 4 bathrooms. Photo: Wow Video Tours

$1.099 million

Balconies abound in this 3,848-square-foot house built in 1996. The master suite has a terrace and a marble bathroom with a double vanity. The kitchen, which has granite countertops and stainless-steel appliances, has a patio. The third-floor family room also has a walkout. Meanwhile, the oversized two-car garage has ample storage. Agent: Julia Packer-Wesselkamper, Coldwell Banker West Shell.

2 bedrooms, 4 bathrooms Photo: Comey & Shepherd Realtors

$1.15 million

A historic property built in 1896, this 5,330-square-foot home features charming details across its three floors like nine-foot ceilings, crown molding, built-in bookcases, and two fireplaces. Of the multiple outdoor spaces, the balcony off of the tiled-floor kitchen is an ideal place for a grill. There is also a butler’s pantry, in-law’s suite, and a fully-finished walkout basement. Agent: Robert Stephens, Comey & Shepherd Realtors.

2 bedrooms, 5 bathrooms. Photo: Chris Farr/The First Showing

$1.35 million

This 4,295-square-foot, three-story contemporary brick home has panoramic Ohio River views from outside terraces on all levels. The kitchen on the second floor has an island with a counter bar, while the family room, which is on the third floor, has a wet bar and patio. There is also an elevator and a heated two-car garage. Agent: Bob Dorger, Comey & Shepherd Realtors.
description: Mt. Adams is one of the oldest–and priciest–communities in the southwestern Ohio city.
